description: WCAG 2.1 verification instructions for AI-powered accessibility analysis

1.1.1.title: Non-text Content
1.1.1.description: All non-text content that is presented to the user has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose
whatToCheck: Check all elements for alt attributes with meaningful descriptions
Check <svg> elements for accessible names (title, aria-label, or aria-labelledby)
Check <canvas> elements for fallback content or aria-label
Check <video> and <audio> elements for text alternatives or descriptions
Check CSS background images used to convey information have text alternatives
Check icon fonts and emoji have accessible text alternatives
Check <object> and <embed> elements for alternative content
Check image maps (<map>, <area>) for alt text on each area
Verify decorative images use empty alt="" or role="presentation"
1.1.1.passCondition: All informative images have descriptive alt text that conveys the same information. Decorative images use alt="" or role="presentation". Complex images have extended descriptions. All media has appropriate text alternatives.
failIndicators: Missing alt attribute on elements
Empty alt attribute on informative images
Alt text that says 'image', 'photo', 'picture', or filename
Alt text that doesn't describe the image content or purpose
Missing accessible names on SVG, canvas, or icon elements
Informative CSS background images without text alternatives
CAPTCHAs without audio or other alternatives
automatedChecksPossible: Detect empty alt on linked images
Detect suspicious alt text patterns (filenames, 'image of')
Detect missing ARIA labels on interactive elements

1.2.1.title: Audio-only and Video-only (Prerecorded)
1.2.1.description: For prerecorded audio-only and prerecorded video-only media, an alternative is provided
whatToCheck: Check for text transcripts near audio-only content (podcasts, audio recordings)
Check for audio descriptions or text descriptions of video-only content (silent videos, animations)
Verify transcripts are accurate and complete
Check that alternatives are clearly labeled and easy to find
1.2.1.passCondition: Audio-only content has a text transcript. Video-only content has either an audio track description or a text description of the visual content.
failIndicators: Audio files without accompanying transcripts
Silent videos or animations without text descriptions
Transcripts that are incomplete or inaccurate
Alternative content that is hidden or difficult to find
automatedChecksPossible: Detect presence of video elements without audio tracks
Check for nearby transcript links or text content

1.2.2.title: Captions (Prerecorded)
1.2.2.description: Captions are provided for all prerecorded audio content in synchronized media
whatToCheck: Check that all <video> elements with audio have captions
Verify captions are synchronized with the audio
Check caption accuracy (speaker identification, sound effects, music)
Verify captions are in the same language as the audio
Check for <track> elements with kind="captions" or kind="subtitles"
Check embedded videos (YouTube, Vimeo) for caption availability
1.2.2.passCondition: All videos with audio content have accurate, synchronized captions that include dialogue, speaker identification, and relevant sound effects.
failIndicators: Videos with audio but no captions
Auto-generated captions without review
Captions that are out of sync with audio
Missing speaker identification in multi-speaker content
Captions that omit important audio information
automatedChecksPossible: Check for <track> elements with caption-related kinds

1.2.3.title: Audio Description or Media Alternative (Prerecorded)
1.2.3.description: An alternative for time-based media or audio description of the prerecorded video content is provided
whatToCheck: Check for audio descriptions that describe visual content
Check for full text transcripts that describe both audio and visual content
Verify audio descriptions include key visual information
Check for links to media alternative or audio description versions
1.2.3.passCondition: Videos have either audio descriptions of visual content or a complete text alternative that describes both the audio and visual content.
failIndicators: Videos with important visual information not conveyed in audio
No audio description track available
No text alternative for video content
Audio descriptions that miss key visual elements

1.2.4.title: Captions (Live)
1.2.4.description: Captions are provided for all live audio content in synchronized media
whatToCheck: Check if live video/audio streams have real-time captions
Verify live captioning service is integrated
Check for CART (Communication Access Real-time Translation) services
Verify caption quality and accuracy for live content
1.2.4.passCondition: Live audio content in synchronized media is accompanied by real-time captions.
failIndicators: Live streams without caption support
Delayed captions that significantly lag behind audio
Low-quality live captions with many errors
No mechanism for live captioning
automatedChecksPossible: Check for caption-related attributes or players

1.2.5.title: Audio Description (Prerecorded)
1.2.5.description: Audio description is provided for all prerecorded video content in synchronized media
whatToCheck: Check for audio description tracks on all videos
Verify audio descriptions adequately describe visual content
Check that audio descriptions don't overlap with dialogue
Verify audio description toggle or separate version is available
1.2.5.passCondition: All prerecorded video content has an audio description track that describes important visual content not conveyed through the main audio track.
failIndicators: Videos without audio description tracks
Audio descriptions that miss important visual information
No mechanism to enable audio descriptions
Audio descriptions that interfere with dialogue

1.3.1.title: Info and Relationships
1.3.1.description: Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined or are available in text
whatToCheck: Check that headings use proper <h1>-<h6> elements in logical order
Check that lists use <ul>, <ol>, or <dl> elements appropriately
Check that data tables have proper <th>, scope, and headers attributes
Check that form labels are properly associated using <label> or aria-labelledby
Check for proper use of landmark regions (header, nav, main, footer)
Check that visual groupings are conveyed programmatically (fieldset/legend)
Verify ARIA roles and attributes are used correctly
Check that emphasized text uses <strong>, <em>, or ARIA
Check that quotes use <blockquote> or <q> elements
1.3.1.passCondition: All structural relationships (headings, lists, tables, forms) are conveyed through proper semantic HTML or ARIA. Visual formatting has programmatic equivalents.
failIndicators: Headings created with CSS styling instead of heading elements
Lists created with line breaks instead of list elements
Data tables without proper header associations
Form inputs without associated labels
Missing landmark regions
Fake tables using CSS Grid/Flexbox for tabular data
Visual-only emphasis (bold/italic) without semantic markup

1.3.2.title: Meaningful Sequence
1.3.2.description: When the sequence in which content is presented affects its meaning, a correct reading sequence can be programmatically determined
whatToCheck: Check that DOM order matches visual presentation order
Check that CSS does not create a misleading reading order
Verify content makes sense when read linearly
Check that tabindex doesn't create confusing navigation order
Verify multi-column layouts read in correct sequence
Check that positioned content maintains logical order
1.3.2.passCondition: The DOM order of content matches the intended reading sequence. Content makes sense when CSS is disabled or when read by a screen reader.
failIndicators: CSS flexbox/grid reordering that breaks logical sequence
Positioned elements that appear in wrong reading order
tabindex values that create illogical focus order
Content that doesn't make sense when linearized
Float layouts that break reading sequence
automatedChecksPossible: Detect CSS order/flex-direction that may affect sequence

1.3.3.title: Sensory Characteristics
1.3.3.description: Instructions provided for understanding and operating content do not rely solely on sensory characteristics such as shape, color, size, visual location, orientation, or sound
whatToCheck: Check that instructions don't rely solely on shape (the round button)
Check that instructions don't rely solely on color (click the red link)
Check that instructions don't rely solely on location (the menu on the right)
Check that instructions don't rely solely on sound (when you hear a beep)
Verify additional text or cues supplement sensory references
Check error messages and help text for sensory-only references
1.3.3.passCondition: All instructions include text labels or other non-sensory identifying information in addition to any sensory characteristics mentioned.
failIndicators: Instructions like 'click the green button' without text label
References to 'the sidebar on the left' without other identification
Instructions based solely on icons without text
Sound-only indicators without visual equivalents
Instructions referencing shape without text labels

1.3.4.title: Orientation
1.3.4.description: Content does not restrict its view and operation to a single display orientation unless a specific display orientation is essential
whatToCheck: Check that content works in both portrait and landscape orientations
Verify no CSS/JavaScript locks orientation unnecessarily
Check for orientation media queries that might restrict content
Verify essential orientation restrictions are documented
1.3.4.passCondition: Content displays and functions properly in both portrait and landscape orientations, unless a specific orientation is essential for the content (e.g., a piano keyboard app).
failIndicators: Content only available in one orientation
JavaScript that forces orientation
CSS that hides content in certain orientations
Prompts telling users to rotate their device (unless essential)

1.3.5.title: Identify Input Purpose
1.3.5.description: The purpose of each input field collecting information about the user can be programmatically determined when the input field serves a common purpose
whatToCheck: Check that form inputs have appropriate autocomplete attributes
Verify autocomplete values match the intended input purpose
Check common fields: name, email, phone, address, payment info
Verify autocomplete is not disabled on user-related fields
1.3.5.passCondition: Form inputs that collect user information (name, email, phone, address, etc.) have appropriate autocomplete attributes that identify their purpose.
failIndicators: Missing autocomplete attributes on common input fields
Incorrect autocomplete values
autocomplete='off' on fields that should support autofill
Custom inputs without proper input purpose identification
automatedChecksPossible: Detect input fields that should have autocomplete
Check for missing autocomplete on common field types

1.4.1.title: Use of Color
1.4.1.description: Color is not used as the only visual means of conveying information, indicating an action, prompting a response, or distinguishing a visual element
whatToCheck: Check that links are distinguishable without color (underline, icon)
Check that required fields have non-color indicators (asterisk, text)
Check that error states have non-color indicators (icon, text, border)
Check that chart/graph data is distinguishable without color (patterns, labels)
Verify form validation doesn't rely solely on color
Check that status indicators use more than just color
1.4.1.passCondition: All information conveyed through color is also available through other visual means such as text, patterns, shapes, or additional formatting.
failIndicators: Links only distinguishable by color
Required fields marked only with color
Errors indicated only by red color
Charts/graphs with color-only data distinction
Status indicators using only color (red/green lights)
Form field validation using only color changes
automatedChecksPossible: Check link color contrast with surrounding text

1.4.2.title: Audio Control
1.4.2.description: If any audio on a Web page plays automatically for more than 3 seconds, either a mechanism is available to pause or stop the audio, or a mechanism is available to control audio volume independently from the overall system volume level
whatToCheck: Check for audio/video that plays automatically on page load
Verify auto-playing media has pause/stop controls
Check for volume control independent of system volume
Verify audio can be muted easily
Check embedded media players for accessible controls
1.4.2.passCondition: Auto-playing audio either stops within 3 seconds, or provides easy-to-find controls to pause, stop, or adjust volume.
failIndicators: Auto-playing audio/video without controls
Background music that cannot be stopped
Audio controls that are hard to find
No mechanism to mute or pause audio
Audio that restarts after being paused

1.4.3.title: Contrast (Minimum)
1.4.3.description: The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for large text (3:1), incidental text, or logotypes
whatToCheck: Check text color contrast against background (minimum 4.5:1)
Check large text contrast (minimum 3:1 for 18pt+ or 14pt+ bold)
Check text over images or gradients
Verify placeholder text meets contrast requirements
Check link text contrast
Check disabled state text (incidental exception)
Check text in form inputs
1.4.3.passCondition: Normal text has at least 4.5:1 contrast ratio. Large text (18pt or 14pt bold) has at least 3:1 contrast ratio. Incidental text and logotypes are exempt.
failIndicators: Text with less than 4.5:1 contrast ratio
Large text with less than 3:1 contrast ratio
Low contrast placeholder text
Text over images without sufficient contrast
Light gray text on white backgrounds

1.4.4.title: Resize Text
1.4.4.description: Except for captions and images of text, text can be resized without assistive technology up to 200 percent without loss of content or functionality
whatToCheck: Test page at 200% browser zoom
Verify no text is cut off or overlapping
Verify no horizontal scrolling is required at 200%
Check that interactive elements remain functional
Verify text doesn't overflow containers
Check that menus and navigation remain usable
1.4.4.passCondition: When text is resized to 200% using browser zoom, all content remains readable without horizontal scrolling, and all functionality remains available.
failIndicators: Text truncated or hidden at 200% zoom
Content overlapping at larger text sizes
Horizontal scrollbar required at 200% zoom
Interactive elements becoming inaccessible
Fixed-size containers cutting off text
Loss of functionality at 200% zoom

1.4.5.title: Images of Text
1.4.5.description: If the technologies being used can achieve the visual presentation, text is used to convey information rather than images of text, except where essential or customizable
whatToCheck: Check for text rendered as images
Verify logos and essential images of text are acceptable
Check for customizable images of text (user can adjust)
Look for images containing significant amounts of text
Check promotional banners and graphics for text content
1.4.5.passCondition: Real text is used instead of images of text, except for logotypes or where the specific visual presentation is essential and cannot be achieved with CSS.
failIndicators: Navigation or buttons rendered as images
Body text content as images
Headers or titles as images (unless logotype)
Images of text that could be rendered with CSS
Screenshots of text used as content
automatedChecksPossible: Detect images with long alt text (possible text image)
OCR detection of text in images
Detect image file sizes suggesting text content

1.4.10.title: Reflow
1.4.10.description: Content can be presented without loss of information or functionality, and without requiring scrolling in two dimensions for: vertical scrolling content at a width of 320 CSS pixels, horizontal scrolling content at a height of 256 CSS pixels
whatToCheck: Test content at 320px width (400% zoom equivalent)
Verify no horizontal scrolling required for vertical content
Check that all content remains accessible
Verify data tables, images, and videos handle reflow appropriately
Check that toolbars and menus adapt to narrow widths
1.4.10.passCondition: At 320 CSS pixels width, content reflows to a single column without horizontal scrolling, and all information and functionality is preserved. Two-dimensional content (data tables, maps) may scroll horizontally.
failIndicators: Horizontal scrollbar at narrow widths
Content cut off at 320px width
Overlapping content at narrow widths
Fixed-width layouts that don't adapt
Loss of functionality on narrow screens
Text that requires horizontal scrolling

1.4.11.title: Non-text Contrast
1.4.11.description: The visual presentation of UI components and graphical objects have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1 against adjacent colors
whatToCheck: Check form input borders have 3:1 contrast
Check button borders/backgrounds have 3:1 contrast
Check focus indicators have 3:1 contrast
Check icons used to convey information have 3:1 contrast
Check chart/graph elements have 3:1 contrast
Check custom controls (sliders, switches) have 3:1 contrast
1.4.11.passCondition: All UI components (form fields, buttons, checkboxes) and meaningful graphical elements have at least 3:1 contrast ratio against their background.
failIndicators: Form inputs with low contrast borders
Buttons with insufficient contrast
Icons with less than 3:1 contrast
Focus indicators with low contrast
Chart elements indistinguishable from background
Custom controls with insufficient contrast
automatedChecksPossible: Check border contrast on form controls

1.4.12.title: Text Spacing
1.4.12.description: No loss of content or functionality occurs when adjusting line height to 1.5x font size, paragraph spacing to 2x font size, letter spacing to 0.12x font size, and word spacing to 0.16x font size
whatToCheck: Test with line-height: 1.5
Test with paragraph spacing (margin-bottom: 2em)
Test with letter-spacing: 0.12em
Test with word-spacing: 0.16em
Verify no text is cut off or hidden
Verify no overlap or collision of elements
1.4.12.passCondition: When text spacing properties are adjusted to WCAG values, all content remains visible and functional without clipping, overlapping, or loss of information.
failIndicators: Text cut off when spacing increased
Content overlapping with increased spacing
Buttons or containers breaking with spacing changes
Loss of functionality due to layout issues
Hidden overflow cutting off text
automatedChecksPossible: Detect overflow:hidden that may clip text
Test layout with injected spacing styles

1.4.13.title: Content on Hover or Focus
1.4.13.description: Where receiving and then removing pointer hover or keyboard focus triggers additional content to become visible and then hidden, the additional content is dismissible, hoverable, and persistent
whatToCheck: Check tooltips can be dismissed without moving pointer/focus
Check hover content can be hovered without disappearing
Check hover/focus content persists until dismissed or trigger loses focus
Verify Escape key dismisses hover content
Check that hover content doesn't obscure trigger or other content
1.4.13.passCondition: Additional content triggered by hover or focus: (1) can be dismissed without moving pointer or focus (e.g., Escape key), (2) can be hovered over without disappearing, and (3) persists until dismissed by user action.
failIndicators: Tooltips that disappear when trying to read them
Hover content that cannot be dismissed
Content that disappears immediately when hover/focus lost
No way to dismiss popup content via keyboard
Hover content that covers other important content

2.1.1.title: Keyboard
2.1.1.description: All functionality of the content is operable through a keyboard interface without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes
whatToCheck: Check that all interactive elements (links, buttons, form fields) are keyboard accessible
Verify all custom controls and widgets can be operated with keyboard
Check that drag-and-drop operations have keyboard alternatives
Verify hover-activated content can be accessed via keyboard focus
Check that onclick handlers on non-interactive elements have keyboard equivalents
Verify custom JavaScript widgets support Tab, Enter, Space, and Arrow keys appropriately
Check that all menu items, tabs, and accordions are keyboard operable
Verify sliders, date pickers, and other complex widgets support keyboard input
2.1.1.passCondition: All interactive content can be accessed and operated using only the keyboard (Tab, Enter, Space, Arrow keys, Escape). No functionality is mouse-only.
failIndicators: Elements only activated by mouse click without keyboard support
Custom controls that cannot receive keyboard focus
onclick handlers without onkeypress/onkeydown equivalents
Drag-and-drop without keyboard alternative
Mouse-over menus without keyboard access
Sliders or carousels that only respond to mouse input
Modal dialogs that cannot be navigated with keyboard
automatedChecksPossible: Detect onclick handlers on non-focusable elements
Check for tabindex on custom interactive elements
Check scrollable regions for keyboard accessibility

2.1.2.title: No Keyboard Trap
2.1.2.description: If keyboard focus can be moved to a component using a keyboard interface, then focus can be moved away from that component using only a keyboard interface
whatToCheck: Check that focus can be moved away from all focused elements using Tab or Shift+Tab
Verify modal dialogs allow focus to escape (via close button or Escape key)
Check that embedded content (iframes, plugins) doesn't trap keyboard focus
Verify custom widgets don't require mouse to exit focus
Check that date pickers, autocomplete, and dropdowns allow keyboard escape
Verify that tabindex values don't create focus traps
2.1.2.passCondition: Users can navigate away from any focused component using standard keyboard navigation (Tab, Shift+Tab, Escape). If special keys are needed, users are informed.
failIndicators: Focus trapped inside modal without Escape key support
Embedded content (Flash, iframes) that traps focus
Custom widgets requiring mouse to exit
Infinite Tab loops within a component
Video players or media controls trapping focus
Rich text editors or code editors trapping focus
automatedChecksPossible: Check for tabindex patterns that might trap focus
Detect modal dialogs and check for Escape key handlers
Check for focus management in custom widgets

2.1.4.title: Character Key Shortcuts
2.1.4.description: If a keyboard shortcut using only letter, punctuation, number, or symbol characters is implemented, then a mechanism is available to turn off or remap the shortcut
whatToCheck: Identify any single-character keyboard shortcuts on the page
Check if shortcuts can be turned off or disabled
Check if shortcuts can be remapped to include modifier keys
Verify shortcuts are only active when relevant component has focus
Check for accesskey attributes using single characters
2.1.4.passCondition: Single-character keyboard shortcuts can be turned off, remapped to use modifier keys (Ctrl, Alt, Shift), or are only active when the component has focus.
failIndicators: Single-key shortcuts that cannot be disabled
Single-key shortcuts that cannot be remapped
Shortcuts that activate regardless of focus location
accesskey attributes that conflict with assistive technology
Global keyboard shortcuts using only letters or numbers
automatedChecksPossible: Detect keydown/keypress handlers listening for single characters
Check for keyboard shortcut configuration options

2.2.1.title: Timing Adjustable
2.2.1.description: For each time limit set by the content, the user can turn off, adjust, or extend the time limit
whatToCheck: Identify any session timeouts or auto-logout functionality
Check for countdown timers on forms or quizzes
Verify time-limited content provides options to extend time
Check for auto-advancing carousels or slideshows with timing
Verify meta refresh tags don't redirect before user can read content
Check for auction or real-time activity exceptions (if applicable)
2.2.1.passCondition: Users can turn off, adjust, or extend time limits before expiration. Exceptions exist for real-time events, essential activities, and limits longer than 20 hours.
failIndicators: Session timeout without warning or extension option
Timed quizzes or forms without time extension
Auto-submitting forms without user control
Meta refresh redirects without user control
Auto-advancing content without pause option
Insufficient time warning before timeout

2.2.2.title: Pause, Stop, Hide
2.2.2.description: For moving, blinking, scrolling, or auto-updating information, there is a mechanism for the user to pause, stop, or hide it
whatToCheck: Check for auto-playing carousels and slideshows
Check for animated banners or advertisements
Check for scrolling news tickers or marquees
Check for auto-updating content (stock tickers, live feeds)
Verify pause/stop controls are provided for moving content
Check for blinking or flashing content
Verify animated GIFs can be stopped
2.2.2.passCondition: Moving, blinking, or scrolling content that starts automatically and lasts more than 5 seconds can be paused, stopped, or hidden. Auto-updating content can be paused, stopped, hidden, or have update frequency controlled.
failIndicators: Auto-playing carousels without pause controls
Animated content without stop mechanism
Scrolling tickers that cannot be paused
Auto-updating feeds without pause option
Blinking text or elements without controls
Animated GIFs that loop continuously without pause option
Background videos without pause controls

2.3.1.title: Three Flashes or Below Threshold
2.3.1.description: Web pages do not contain anything that flashes more than three times in any one second period, or the flash is below the general flash and red flash thresholds
whatToCheck: Check for flashing or strobing content in videos
Check for rapid CSS animations or transitions
Check for flashing advertisements or banners
Check for rapidly changing images or GIFs
Verify any flashing content is below threshold (small area or low contrast)
Check for JavaScript-driven flashing effects
2.3.1.passCondition: No content flashes more than 3 times per second, or flashing content is small enough (less than 25% of viewport) and low contrast enough to be below the general flash threshold.
failIndicators: Videos with strobe or flashing effects
Rapid CSS animations causing flash-like effects
Flashing banner advertisements
GIFs with rapid color changes
JavaScript animations causing rapid flashing
Content with rapid brightness changes
automatedChecksPossible: Detect GIFs (require manual flash rate check)

2.4.1.title: Bypass Blocks
2.4.1.description: A mechanism is available to bypass blocks of content that are repeated on multiple web pages
whatToCheck: Check for 'skip to main content' or 'skip navigation' links
Verify skip links are visible on keyboard focus
Check that skip links target the correct destination
Verify proper use of ARIA landmarks (main, nav, banner, contentinfo)
Check for proper heading structure to allow heading navigation
Verify skip links are among the first focusable elements
2.4.1.passCondition: Users can bypass repeated content blocks using skip links, ARIA landmarks, or proper heading structure. Skip links become visible on focus and function correctly.
failIndicators: No skip link to main content
Skip links that don't function (broken targets)
Skip links hidden even on focus
Missing ARIA landmark regions
No heading structure for screen reader navigation
Skip links not among first focusable elements
automatedChecksPossible: Detect skip links and verify targets
Check for ARIA landmark regions (main, nav, banner)
Check skip link visibility on focus

2.4.2.title: Page Titled
2.4.2.description: Web pages have titles that describe topic or purpose
whatToCheck: Check that <title> element exists in <head>
Verify title describes the page topic or purpose
Check that title is unique within the website
Verify title is not generic ('Home', 'Page 1', 'Untitled')
Check that title updates for single-page applications
Verify title includes site name and specific page identifier
2.4.2.passCondition: Each page has a <title> that accurately describes its topic or purpose, is unique within the site, and distinguishes the page from other pages.
failIndicators: Missing <title> element
Empty or whitespace-only title
Generic titles like 'Untitled', 'Home', 'Page'
Same title used on multiple different pages
Title doesn't describe page content
Title not updated on SPA route changes
automatedChecksPossible: Check for empty or generic titles
Verify title is not just the site name
Check title length (not too short or too long)

2.4.3.title: Focus Order
2.4.3.description: If a web page can be navigated sequentially and the navigation sequences affect meaning or operation, focusable components receive focus in an order that preserves meaning and operability
whatToCheck: Tab through all interactive elements and verify logical order
Check that focus order matches visual reading order
Verify tabindex values don't create illogical focus order
Check modal dialogs maintain focus within the dialog
Verify focus moves logically through forms
Check that dynamically added content receives focus appropriately
2.4.3.passCondition: When navigating with Tab key, focus moves through interactive elements in a logical order that matches the visual layout and preserves meaning.
failIndicators: Focus order doesn't match visual order
Positive tabindex values creating confusing order
Focus jumping unexpectedly around the page
Focus moving to hidden or off-screen elements
Modal dialogs allowing focus to escape to background
Form fields in illogical tab order
automatedChecksPossible: Compare DOM order with visual order
Detect focus management issues in modals
Check for tabindex on non-interactive elements

2.4.4.title: Link Purpose (In Context)
2.4.4.description: The purpose of each link can be determined from the link text alone or from the link text together with its programmatically determined link context
whatToCheck: Check that link text describes the destination or purpose
Verify 'click here', 'read more', 'learn more' links have context
Check that image links have descriptive alt text
Verify link purpose is clear from surrounding context (sentence, paragraph, list item)
Check that links with same text go to same destination
Verify aria-label or aria-labelledby provides additional context when needed
2.4.4.passCondition: Each link's purpose can be determined from the link text alone, or from the link text combined with its programmatically determined context (enclosing sentence, paragraph, list item, table cell, or associated header).
failIndicators: Ambiguous links like 'click here' without context
'Read more' links without identifying what will be read
Multiple 'Learn more' links without differentiation
Image links without descriptive alt text
Links with identical text going to different destinations
Links that only make sense visually (based on position)
automatedChecksPossible: Check for empty or missing link text
Detect image-only links without alt text
Check for aria-label on ambiguous links

2.4.5.title: Multiple Ways
2.4.5.description: More than one way is available to locate a web page within a set of web pages, except where the page is the result of, or a step in, a process
whatToCheck: Check for site navigation menu
Check for site search functionality
Check for sitemap page
Check for table of contents (for long documents)
Verify links between related pages
Check for breadcrumb navigation
2.4.5.passCondition: At least two of the following are available to find pages: navigation menus, search function, site map, table of contents, or links from related pages. Exception for process steps.
failIndicators: Only one way to navigate to pages
No search functionality on large sites
No sitemap available
No navigation between related content
Sequential-only access to content

2.4.6.title: Headings and Labels
2.4.6.description: Headings and labels describe topic or purpose
whatToCheck: Check that headings accurately describe the content that follows
Verify form labels clearly describe the expected input
Check that headings are not used solely for visual styling
Verify section headings identify section content
Check that button labels describe their action
Verify fieldset legends describe the group purpose
2.4.6.passCondition: All headings describe their following content. All form labels describe expected input. Labels and headings are descriptive, not just decorative.
failIndicators: Vague headings like 'Section 1', 'More Information'
Form labels that don't describe expected input
Headings used only for visual styling without semantic meaning
Generic button labels like 'Submit' without context
Misleading headings that don't match content
automatedChecksPossible: Detect presence of headings and labels
Check for empty or very short headings
Verify form elements have associated labels

2.4.7.title: Focus Visible
2.4.7.description: Any keyboard operable user interface has a mode of operation where the keyboard focus indicator is visible
whatToCheck: Tab through all interactive elements and verify focus is visible
Check that focus indicator has sufficient contrast
Verify custom focus styles don't remove visibility
Check that outline: none is not used without alternative focus style
Verify focus is visible on all interactive elements (links, buttons, inputs)
Check focus visibility in high contrast mode
2.4.7.passCondition: When navigating with keyboard, the currently focused element is always visually distinguishable from other elements through a visible focus indicator.
failIndicators: CSS outline: none without alternative focus style
Focus indicator with insufficient contrast
Custom controls without visible focus state
Focus indicator too subtle to be noticed
Some elements lacking focus indicators
Focus indicator hidden by adjacent elements
automatedChecksPossible: Verify all focusable elements have focus styles

2.5.1.title: Pointer Gestures
2.5.1.description: All functionality that uses multipoint or path-based gestures for operation can be operated with a single pointer without a path-based gesture
whatToCheck: Check for pinch-to-zoom functionality (has alternative like buttons)
Check for swipe gestures (has alternative like arrows or buttons)
Check for multi-finger gestures (has single-finger or click alternatives)
Verify drag-and-drop has click-based alternative
Check for drawing or freehand path gestures (has alternatives)
Verify maps and interactive graphics have button controls
2.5.1.passCondition: Any functionality requiring multi-point gestures (pinch, multi-touch) or path-based gestures (swiping, dragging) has single-pointer alternatives (tap, click).
failIndicators: Pinch-to-zoom without button alternative
Swipe-only navigation without arrows or buttons
Multi-touch gestures without single-pointer alternative
Path-based drawing required without alternatives
Slider that requires dragging without click-to-set
automatedChecksPossible: Check for alternative controls near gesture areas

2.5.2.title: Pointer Cancellation
2.5.2.description: For functionality that can be operated using a single pointer, at least one of the following is true: no down-event, can abort or undo, up reversal, or essential
whatToCheck: Check that actions execute on mouse-up, not mouse-down
Verify dragging away from target before release cancels action
Check for undo functionality for pointer-triggered actions
Verify accidental clicks can be avoided by moving pointer away
Check submit buttons don't trigger on mousedown
2.5.2.passCondition: Single-pointer actions either: trigger on up-event (not down-event), can be aborted by moving pointer away, can be undone after completion, or down-event is essential.
failIndicators: Actions triggered on mousedown without reversal option
Click actions that cannot be cancelled by moving away
Destructive actions without undo option
Critical functionality triggered on pointer down-event
automatedChecksPossible: Check for click vs mousedown event usage
Detect touchstart handlers without cancellation logic

2.5.3.title: Label in Name
2.5.3.description: For user interface components with labels that include text or images of text, the name contains the text that is presented visually
whatToCheck: Check that visible button text matches accessible name
Verify icon buttons with visible labels include that text in accessible name
Check form field labels match their accessible names
Verify image buttons include visible text in alt attribute
Check aria-label includes visible text (not just replaces it)
Verify links' accessible names include visible link text
2.5.3.passCondition: For all UI components with visible text labels, the accessible name (computed from aria-label, aria-labelledby, or native semantics) contains the visible text.
failIndicators: aria-label that doesn't include visible text
Button with different aria-label than visible text
Icon with visible label but aria-label doesn't match
Form field with label text not in accessible name
Image with text where alt doesn't match visible text
automatedChecksPossible: Compare visible text with aria-label content
Check that aria-label contains visible text
Detect mismatch between label and accessible name
Verify button text matches accessible name

2.5.4.title: Motion Actuation
2.5.4.description: Functionality that can be operated by device motion or user motion can also be operated by user interface components and responding to the motion can be disabled
whatToCheck: Check for shake-to-undo or shake-triggered actions
Check for tilt or device orientation-based controls
Check for motion-based gestures (wave, nod detection)
Verify alternative UI controls exist for motion actions
Check for option to disable motion-based responses
Verify accelerometer/gyroscope features have alternatives
2.5.4.passCondition: Any functionality triggered by device motion (shaking, tilting) or user motion has equivalent UI component controls, and motion response can be disabled to prevent accidental activation.
failIndicators: Shake-to-undo without button alternative
Tilt-to-scroll without alternative controls
Motion-only features without UI alternatives
No option to disable motion responses
Essential actions only available via motion

3.1.1.title: Language of Page
3.1.1.description: The default human language of each web page can be programmatically determined
whatToCheck: Check that the <html> element has a valid lang attribute
Verify the lang attribute value matches the primary language of the page content
Check that the lang attribute uses a valid BCP 47 language tag (e.g., 'en', 'en-US', 'es', 'fr')
Verify the lang attribute is not empty or invalid
Check that the xml:lang attribute matches lang if both are present (XHTML)
3.1.1.passCondition: The <html> element has a lang attribute with a valid language code that accurately identifies the primary language of the page content.
failIndicators: Missing lang attribute on <html> element
Empty lang attribute
Invalid language code format
Language code doesn't match actual page content language
Mismatch between lang and xml:lang attributes
automatedChecksPossible: Detect presence of lang attribute on <html>
Validate lang attribute format against BCP 47
Check for empty or missing lang values

3.1.2.title: Language of Parts
3.1.2.description: The human language of each passage or phrase in the content can be programmatically determined except for proper names, technical terms, words of indeterminate language, and words or phrases that have become part of the vernacular
whatToCheck: Check that text in a different language from the page default has a lang attribute
Verify foreign language quotes, phrases, or passages are marked with appropriate lang attribute
Check that language changes are marked on the containing element or span
Verify technical terms, proper names, and loan words that don't need marking
Check multilingual content for proper language identification
3.1.2.passCondition: All passages or phrases in a different language from the page's default language are identified with the lang attribute, except for proper names, technical terms, and commonly understood loan words.
failIndicators: Foreign language text without lang attribute
Incorrect language code on multilingual content
Large sections of different-language text unmarked
Mixed language content without proper demarcation
automatedChecksPossible: Detect potential foreign language text patterns
Check for lang attributes on text within the page
Validate language codes on embedded content
Compare text content with declared language

3.2.1.title: On Focus
3.2.1.description: When any user interface component receives focus, it does not initiate a change of context
whatToCheck: Check that focusing on form fields doesn't trigger form submission
Verify focusing on links doesn't navigate to a new page
Check that focusing on elements doesn't open new windows or popups
Verify focusing doesn't cause significant content changes
Check that tab focus on navigation items doesn't auto-expand menus unexpectedly
Verify focus doesn't trigger modal dialogs or overlays
3.2.1.passCondition: Moving focus to any element (via Tab key or programmatically) does not cause a change of context such as form submission, page navigation, new window opening, or significant content reorganization.
failIndicators: Form submits when field receives focus
New window or tab opens on focus
Page navigates away when element receives focus
Major content changes occur when element is focused
Unexpected modal or popup appears on focus
Auto-submit or auto-action triggered by onfocus event
automatedChecksPossible: Detect window.open calls in focus handlers
Check for form.submit calls in focus handlers

3.2.2.title: On Input
3.2.2.description: Changing the setting of any user interface component does not automatically cause a change of context unless the user has been advised of the behavior before using the component
whatToCheck: Check that selecting a radio button doesn't submit a form automatically
Verify changing a dropdown selection doesn't navigate to a new page
Check that checking a checkbox doesn't trigger unexpected actions
Verify typing in a text field doesn't auto-submit or navigate
Check that users are warned if input changes will cause context changes
Verify search-as-you-type doesn't navigate away unexpectedly
3.2.2.passCondition: Changing input values (selecting options, checking boxes, typing) does not trigger context changes unless the user is warned beforehand. A submit button or explicit action is required for context changes.
failIndicators: Dropdown selection auto-navigates to new page
Radio button selection auto-submits form
Checkbox triggers unexpected modal or navigation
Text input causes page refresh or navigation
No warning provided before context-changing input
onChange handlers that submit forms or navigate
automatedChecksPossible: Detect onchange event handlers on form elements
Check for form.submit calls in change handlers
Detect navigation in select/radio change handlers
Check for context-change warnings near inputs

3.2.3.title: Consistent Navigation
3.2.3.description: Navigational mechanisms that are repeated on multiple web pages within a set of web pages occur in the same relative order each time they are repeated, unless a change is initiated by the user
whatToCheck: Check that main navigation appears in the same position across pages
Verify navigation links are in the same order across pages
Check that repeated components (header, footer, sidebar) maintain position
Verify search functionality appears in consistent location
Check that skip links appear in the same position
Verify breadcrumbs and secondary navigation are consistently placed
3.2.3.passCondition: Navigation menus, links, and other repeated navigational elements appear in the same relative order and position across all pages within the website, unless the user has customized the layout.
failIndicators: Navigation items in different order on different pages
Header/footer components repositioned between pages
Search box moving to different locations
Skip links appearing inconsistently
Secondary navigation changing position
Inconsistent placement of login/account links
automatedChecksPossible: Compare navigation structure across multiple pages

3.2.4.title: Consistent Identification
3.2.4.description: Components that have the same functionality within a set of web pages are identified consistently
whatToCheck: Check that search fields are labeled consistently across pages
Verify submit buttons use consistent labels ('Submit', 'Send', 'Go')
Check that icons representing same function have consistent alt text
Verify navigation links to same destination use consistent text
Check that form fields for same data use consistent labels
Verify print, share, download icons are labeled consistently
3.2.4.passCondition: Components with the same functionality (search, submit, navigation, icons) are identified with consistent labels, names, and text alternatives throughout the website.
failIndicators: Search labeled as 'Search' on one page and 'Find' on another
Submit buttons with inconsistent labels
Same icon with different alt text across pages
Same link destination with different link text
Form fields for same data with different labels
Inconsistent naming of recurring interface elements

3.3.1.title: Error Identification
3.3.1.description: If an input error is automatically detected, the item that is in error is identified and the error is described to the user in text
whatToCheck: Check that form validation errors are displayed as text (not just color)
Verify the specific field with error is identified
Check that error messages describe what went wrong
Verify error messages are programmatically associated with fields (aria-describedby)
Check that errors are announced to screen readers (aria-live or role='alert')
Verify error state is indicated with more than just color
3.3.1.passCondition: When input errors occur, the specific field is identified and a text description explains the error. Errors are programmatically associated with their fields and announced to assistive technology.
failIndicators: Errors indicated only by color change
Generic error messages without field identification
No text description of what error occurred
Error messages not associated with form fields
Errors not announced to screen readers
Vague error messages like 'Invalid input'
automatedChecksPossible: Check for aria-describedby on form fields
Check for role='alert' on error messages
Verify error indicators use more than color

3.3.2.title: Labels or Instructions
3.3.2.description: Labels or instructions are provided when content requires user input
whatToCheck: Check that all form inputs have visible labels
Verify labels are programmatically associated with inputs
Check that required fields are indicated (asterisk, 'required' text)
Verify format requirements are provided (e.g., 'MM/DD/YYYY')
Check that complex inputs have helpful instructions
Verify placeholder text is not used as the only label
3.3.2.passCondition: All form fields have clear, visible labels that are programmatically associated. Instructions for required fields, expected formats, and complex inputs are provided.
failIndicators: Form inputs without visible labels
Labels not programmatically associated with inputs
Required fields not indicated
No format hints for date, phone, or other formatted fields
Placeholder text used as the only label
Complex inputs without instructions

3.3.3.title: Error Suggestion
3.3.3.description: If an input error is automatically detected and suggestions for correction are known, then the suggestions are provided to the user, unless it would jeopardize security or purpose
whatToCheck: Check that error messages include suggestions for fixing the error
Verify format errors suggest the correct format
Check that out-of-range errors indicate the allowed range
Verify suggestions don't compromise security (e.g., valid usernames)
Check that suggestions are specific and actionable
Verify password errors don't reveal security-sensitive rules unnecessarily
3.3.3.passCondition: Error messages include specific suggestions for how to correct the error, such as expected format, allowed values, or example input. Security-sensitive fields may omit specific suggestions.
failIndicators: Error messages without correction suggestions
Format errors without showing expected format
Out-of-range errors without showing allowed range
Generic 'invalid' messages without guidance
Required field errors without clear guidance
Suggestions that could compromise security
automatedChecksPossible: Analyze error message content for suggestions
Check for format examples in error messages
Detect generic vs specific error patterns

3.3.4.title: Error Prevention (Legal, Financial, Data)
3.3.4.description: For web pages that cause legal commitments or financial transactions, or that modify or delete user-controllable data, submissions are reversible, verified, or confirmed
whatToCheck: Check for confirmation pages before final submission of financial transactions
Verify ability to review and edit data before legal commitments
Check for 'Are you sure?' confirmations for data deletion
Verify submitted data can be reversed, corrected, or cancelled
Check for review step showing all entered information
Verify edit capabilities on confirmation/review pages
3.3.4.passCondition: For legal, financial, or data-modifying transactions, at least one of: (1) submissions are reversible, (2) data is checked for errors with correction opportunity, or (3) a confirmation step allows review before final submission.
failIndicators: Immediate financial transaction without confirmation
Legal agreements submitted without review step
Data deletion without confirmation dialog
No ability to edit data after entering
No review page before final submission
Irreversible actions without user confirmation

4.1.1.title: Parsing
4.1.1.description: In content implemented using markup languages, elements have complete start and end tags, elements are nested according to their specifications, elements do not contain duplicate attributes, and any IDs are unique (Note: This criterion was deprecated in WCAG 2.2 as browsers now handle parsing errors)
whatToCheck: Check for duplicate ID attributes on elements
Verify elements have proper opening and closing tags
Check for properly nested elements (no overlapping tags)
Verify no duplicate attributes on the same element
Check that obsolete elements are not used inappropriately
Verify HTML validates against the doctype specification
4.1.1.passCondition: HTML is well-formed with no duplicate IDs, properly nested elements, complete start/end tags, and no duplicate attributes. Note: Modern browsers handle most parsing errors, but duplicate IDs can still cause accessibility issues.
failIndicators: Duplicate ID attributes on multiple elements
Unclosed or improperly nested tags
Duplicate attributes on same element
Invalid markup that could confuse assistive technology
Missing required parent/child element relationships

4.1.2.title: Name, Role, Value
4.1.2.description: For all user interface components, the name and role can be programmatically determined; states, properties, and values that can be set by the user can be programmatically set; and notification of changes is available to user agents, including assistive technologies
whatToCheck: Check that custom controls have appropriate ARIA roles
Verify all interactive elements have accessible names
Check that custom widgets expose their state (expanded, selected, checked)
Verify value changes in custom controls are announced
Check that native HTML elements are used appropriately
Verify ARIA properties reflect the current state
4.1.2.passCondition: All UI components have programmatically determinable names and roles. Custom controls expose their state, properties, and values to assistive technology. State changes trigger appropriate notifications.
failIndicators: Custom controls without ARIA roles
Interactive elements without accessible names
Custom widgets not exposing expanded/collapsed state
Toggle buttons not exposing pressed state
Select-like controls not exposing selected value
State changes not announced to assistive technology
automatedChecksPossible: Check for accessible names on interactive elements
Verify ARIA roles on custom controls

4.1.3.title: Status Messages
4.1.3.description: In content implemented using markup languages, status messages can be programmatically determined through role or properties such that they can be presented to the user by assistive technologies without receiving focus
whatToCheck: Check that success messages use aria-live='polite' or role='status'
Verify error messages use aria-live='assertive' or role='alert'
Check that progress updates are announced (aria-live)
Verify search results count changes are announced
Check that loading indicators convey status to screen readers
Verify form submission success/failure is announced
4.1.3.passCondition: Status messages (success, error, progress, results) are programmatically associated with ARIA live regions or status roles so they are announced by assistive technology without moving focus.
failIndicators: Success messages not announced to screen readers
Error messages without aria-live or role='alert'
Progress indicators silent to assistive technology
Search result counts not announced
Loading states not communicated
Form submission results not announced
automatedChecksPossible: Check for dynamic content update announcements
